prompt: Choose the correct form: 'I _____ to school every day.'
explanationTemplate: Use simple present tense for habitual actions. The correct answer is 'go'.
exampleSentence: I go to school every day.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'I _____ to the store yesterday.'
explanationTemplate: Use simple past tense for completed actions in the past. The correct answer is 'went'.
exampleSentence: I went to the store yesterday.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'She _____ reading a book when I called.'
explanationTemplate: Use past continuous (was/were + verb-ing) for actions in progress at a specific time in the past.
exampleSentence: She was reading a book when I called.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'I _____ here for five years.'
explanationTemplate: Use present perfect (have/has + past participle) for actions that started in the past and continue to the present.
exampleSentence: I have lived here for five years.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'By the time you arrive, I _____ dinner.'
explanationTemplate: Use future perfect (will have + past participle) for actions that will be completed before a future time.
exampleSentence: By the time you arrive, I will have finished dinner.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'By next month, I _____ here for a year.'
explanationTemplate: Use future perfect (will have + past participle) for actions that will be completed before a future time point.
exampleSentence: By next month, I will have worked here for a year.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'By the time she arrived, I _____ already left.'
explanationTemplate: Use past perfect (had + past participle) for actions completed before another past action.
exampleSentence: By the time she arrived, I had already left.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'They _____ playing soccer right now.'
explanationTemplate: Use present continuous (am/is/are + verb-ing) for actions happening now or around now.
exampleSentence: They are playing soccer right now.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I _____ been waiting for an hour.'
explanationTemplate: Use present perfect continuous (have/has been + verb-ing) for actions that started in the past and continue to now.
exampleSentence: I have been waiting for an hour.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'She _____ working here since 2020.'
explanationTemplate: Use present perfect continuous (have/has been + verb-ing) with 'since' or 'for' to show duration.
exampleSentence: She has been working here since 2020.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'By next year, I _____ studying English for ten years.'
explanationTemplate: Use future perfect continuous (will have been + verb-ing) for actions that will continue up to a future time.
exampleSentence: By next year, I will have been studying English for ten years.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'When I arrived, they _____ already finished dinner.'
explanationTemplate: Use past perfect (had + past participle) to show an action completed before another past action.
exampleSentence: When I arrived, they had already finished dinner.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'I usually _____ coffee in the morning.'
explanationTemplate: Use simple present for habits and routines. 'Usually' indicates a regular habit.
exampleSentence: I usually drink coffee in the morning.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'She _____ been living in London for three years before she moved.'
explanationTemplate: Use past perfect continuous (had been + verb-ing) for actions that continued up to a point in the past.
exampleSentence: She had been living in London for three years before she moved.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'Next week, I _____ to Japan.'
explanationTemplate: Use present continuous (am/is/are + verb-ing) for future plans and arrangements.
exampleSentence: Next week, I am going to Japan.

prompt: Choose the correct modal: 'You _____ study harder to pass the exam.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'must' to express strong necessity or obligation.
exampleSentence: You must study harder to pass the exam.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'I _____ have left my keys at home.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'must have + past participle' to express a logical conclusion about a past event.
exampleSentence: I must have left my keys at home.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'You _____ have told me earlier!'
explanationTemplate: Use 'should have + past participle' to express regret about past actions that didn't happen.
exampleSentence: You should have told me earlier!

prompt: Choose the correct modal: '_____ I help you with that?'
explanationTemplate: Use 'Can' or 'May' to offer help politely. 'Can' is more common in informal situations.
exampleSentence: Can I help you with that?

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'You _____ not smoke here. It's prohibited.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'must not' to express prohibition. 'Must not' means something is not allowed.
exampleSentence: You must not smoke here. It's prohibited.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'You _____ borrow my book if you want.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'can' to express permission or ability.
exampleSentence: You can borrow my book if you want.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'She _____ have forgotten about the meeting.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'might have' or 'could have' to express possibility about past events. 'Might' suggests less certainty than 'must'.
exampleSentence: She might have forgotten about the meeting.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I _____ have done better if I had studied more.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'could have + past participle' to express past ability or possibility that didn't happen.
exampleSentence: I could have done better if I had studied more.

prompt: Choose the correct modal: '_____ you please pass me the salt?'
explanationTemplate: Use 'Could' or 'Would' to make polite requests. 'Could' is common for asking favors.
exampleSentence: Could you please pass me the salt?

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'You _____ have been more careful!'
explanationTemplate: Use 'should have + past participle' to express criticism or regret about past actions.
exampleSentence: You should have been more careful!

prompt: Complete the sentence: 'If I _____ known, I would have gone.'
explanationTemplate: This is a third conditional. Use 'had + past participle' in the if-clause for past hypothetical situations.
exampleSentence: If I had known, I would have gone.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'If it rains tomorrow, I _____ stay home.'
explanationTemplate: This is a first conditional. Use 'will + base verb' in the main clause for real future possibilities.
exampleSentence: If it rains tomorrow, I will stay home.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'If I _____ you, I would study harder.'
explanationTemplate: This is a second conditional. Use 'were' (not 'was') for all subjects in the if-clause, even with 'I'.
exampleSentence: If I were you, I would study harder.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'If you heat water to 100°C, it _____.'
explanationTemplate: This is a zero conditional for general truths. Use simple present in both clauses.
exampleSentence: If you heat water to 100°C, it boils.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'If I _____ studied harder, I would have passed the exam.'
explanationTemplate: This is a third conditional. Use 'had + past participle' in the if-clause for past hypothetical situations.
exampleSentence: If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'If she _____ call, tell her I'm busy.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'should' in first conditional to make it less likely or more formal. 'If she should call' means 'if by chance she calls'.
exampleSentence: If she should call, tell her I'm busy.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'If I had known you were coming, I _____ prepared dinner.'
explanationTemplate: This is a third conditional. Use 'would have + past participle' in the main clause.
exampleSentence: If I had known you were coming, I would have prepared dinner.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'If I _____ rich, I would travel the world.'
explanationTemplate: This is a second conditional. Use 'were' (not 'was') for all subjects in hypothetical situations.
exampleSentence: If I were rich, I would travel the world.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'Unless you study, you _____ pass the exam.'
explanationTemplate: 'Unless' means 'if not'. Use first conditional structure: 'Unless + present, will + base verb'.
exampleSentence: Unless you study, you won't pass the exam.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'If I _____ you, I would have accepted the offer.'
explanationTemplate: This is a mixed conditional (past condition, present result). Use 'had been' in the if-clause.
exampleSentence: If I had been you, I would have accepted the offer.

prompt: Choose the best sentence combination: 'The book was interesting. I read it last week.'
explanationTemplate: Use a relative clause to combine the sentences. 'That' or 'which' can refer to the book.
exampleSentence: The book that I read last week was interesting.

choices.text: The book was interesting, I read it last week.
The book that I read last week was interesting.
The book was interesting that I read last week.
The book interesting I read last week.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'which' for non-restrictive clauses (with comma) and 'that' for restrictive clauses (no comma).
exampleSentence: The movie, which was released last year, won many awards.

choices.text: The movie that was released last year, won many awards.
The movie, that was released last year won many awards.
The movie, which was released last year, won many awards.
The movie which was released last year, won many awards.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'who' for people as subjects in relative clauses. 'The students' is the subject, so use 'who'.
exampleSentence: The students who study hard usually get good grades.

choices.text: The students who study hard usually get good grades.
The students which study hard usually get good grades.
The students that study hard usually get good grades.
The students whom study hard usually get good grades.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses. 'The place' refers to a location, so use 'where'.
exampleSentence: This is the place where I first met her.

choices.text: This is the place where I first met her.
This is the place which I first met her.
This is the place that I first met her.
This is the place who I first met her.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'I finished my homework. I went to bed.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'after' to show the sequence of events. 'After finishing' or 'After I finished' are both correct.
exampleSentence: After finishing my homework, I went to bed.

choices.text: After finishing my homework, I went to bed.
I finished my homework, I went to bed.
I finished my homework. After I went to bed.
After I finished my homework. I went to bed.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'She was tired. She continued working.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'although' or 'even though' to show contrast. Place the subordinate clause first or second.
exampleSentence: Although she was tired, she continued working.

choices.text: She was tired, she continued working.
Although she was tired, she continued working.
She was tired. Although she continued working.
She was tired although she continued working.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'It was raining. We went outside anyway.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'even though' or 'although' to show contrast. Both clauses are connected with a comma.
exampleSentence: Even though it was raining, we went outside anyway.

choices.text: It was raining, we went outside anyway.
Even though it was raining, we went outside anyway.
It was raining. Even though we went outside anyway.
It was raining even though we went outside anyway.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I saw _____ elephant at the zoo.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound. 'Elephant' starts with a vowel sound.
exampleSentence: I saw an elephant at the zoo.

prompt: Choose the correct article: '_____ sun rises in the east.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'the' with unique things like 'sun', 'moon', 'earth'.
exampleSentence: The sun rises in the east.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I need _____ hour to finish this.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound. 'Hour' starts with a vowel sound (silent 'h').
exampleSentence: I need an hour to finish this.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I love _____ music.'
explanationTemplate: Use no article with uncountable nouns when speaking in general. 'Music' is uncountable and general here.
exampleSentence: I love music.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'The students _____ studying hard.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'are' (plural) with 'students' (plural subject). Subject-verb agreement: plural subject needs plural verb.
exampleSentence: The students are studying hard.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'Neither the teacher nor the students _____ happy.'
explanationTemplate: With 'neither...nor', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it. 'Students' is plural, so use 'are'.
exampleSentence: Neither the teacher nor the students are happy.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'The number of students _____ increasing.'
explanationTemplate: 'The number of' is singular, so use 'is'. 'A number of' would be plural.
exampleSentence: The number of students is increasing.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'The committee _____ decided to postpone the meeting.'
explanationTemplate: 'Committee' can be singular (as a group) or plural (as individuals). Here it's treated as singular, so use 'has'.
exampleSentence: The committee has decided to postpone the meeting.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'The teacher explained the lesson.'
explanationTemplate: Passive voice: be + past participle. The object becomes the subject, and the original subject becomes optional (with 'by').
exampleSentence: The lesson was explained by the teacher.

choices.text: The teacher was explained the lesson.
The lesson explained by the teacher.
The lesson was explained by the teacher.
The lesson is explaining by the teacher.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The building _____ built last year.'
explanationTemplate: Use past tense 'was' (singular) or 'were' (plural) + past participle for passive voice in the past.
exampleSentence: The building was built last year.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'Someone has stolen my bike.'
explanationTemplate: Use present perfect passive: 'has/have been + past participle'. 'Has stolen' becomes 'has been stolen'.
exampleSentence: My bike has been stolen.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'People speak English all over the world.'
explanationTemplate: Use simple present passive: 'is/are + past participle'. 'People speak' becomes 'English is spoken'.
exampleSentence: English is spoken all over the world.

choices.text: English speaks all over the world.
English is spoken all over the world.
English was spoken all over the world.
English has spoken all over the world.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'I am tired,' she said.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, change present tense to past tense. 'I am' becomes 'she was'.
exampleSentence: She said that she was tired.

choices.text: She said that I am tired.
She said that she was tired.
She said that she is tired.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'I will come tomorrow,' he said.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, 'will' becomes 'would' and 'tomorrow' becomes 'the next day' or 'the following day'.
exampleSentence: He said that he would come the next day.

choices.text: He said that he will come tomorrow.
He said that he would come tomorrow.
He said that he would come the next day.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'I have finished my homework,' he said.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, present perfect becomes past perfect. 'I have finished' becomes 'he had finished'.
exampleSentence: He said that he had finished his homework.

choices.text: He said that he has finished his homework.
He said that he finished his homework.
He said that he had finished his homework.
He said he finishes his homework.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'Don't touch that!' she said.
explanationTemplate: Imperatives in reported speech use 'told/asked + object + (not) to + verb'. 'Don't touch' becomes 'not to touch'.
exampleSentence: She told me not to touch that.

choices.text: She said that I don't touch that.
She told me not to touch that.
She said I not touch that.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: 'I will meet you _____ 3 PM.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'at' for specific times of day.
exampleSentence: I will meet you at 3 PM.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The book is _____ the table.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'on' for things that are in contact with a surface.
exampleSentence: The book is on the table.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: 'I will finish this _____ Friday.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'by' to indicate a deadline or the latest time something will happen.
exampleSentence: I will finish this by Friday.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I'm interested _____ learning English.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'interested in' (not 'interested for' or 'interested about').
exampleSentence: I'm interested in learning English.

prompt: Choose the correct relative pronoun: 'The person _____ I met yesterday was very kind.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'whom' (or 'who' in informal English) for people as objects. 'That' can also be used.
exampleSentence: The person whom I met yesterday was very kind.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'whose' to show possession in adjective clauses. 'Whose' can refer to people or things.
exampleSentence: The student whose book was lost asked for help.

choices.text: The student who book was lost asked for help.
The student which book was lost asked for help.
The student that book was lost asked for help.
The student whose book was lost asked for help.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'when' for time in adjective clauses. 'The time' refers to when something happened.
exampleSentence: I remember the time when we first met.

choices.text: I remember the time which we first met.
I remember the time when we first met.
I remember the time where we first met.
I remember the time that we first met.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'Each student must bring _____ own book.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'his or her' (or 'their' in modern English) with 'each'. 'Each' is singular.
exampleSentence: Each student must bring his or her own book.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'The team won _____ first match.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'its' (not 'it's') for possessive form of 'it'. 'It's' means 'it is'.
exampleSentence: The team won its first match.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'The students helped _____ prepare for the exam.'
explanationTemplate: Use reflexive pronouns (myself, yourself, himself, etc.) when the subject and object are the same.
exampleSentence: The students helped themselves prepare for the exam.
